comments.body: this is very awkward to do. Maybe just put the immutable definition in base and override the definition in series. prob simpler?

OK, fixed to centralize the logic to `IndexOpsMixin`. Even though `update_inplace` is defined in both `IndexOpsMixin` and `Index`, it will never called in `drop_duplicates` case (`Index.drop_duplicates` blocks `inplace` kw, and it is better for proper `docstring`)
ok with changing to this, though using `(~values).astype(bool)` is quite common in the code base - if someone wanted to clean up this would be appreciated

@shoyer @jreback I improved the checking here according to your recommendations - in the case of `Series` it's the same logic as before and in the case of `Index` it uses the `inferred_type` attribute

I don't think you can accept `mixed-integer`, as these are in general python integer objects which need stringification first (which we _could_ do, but that's a separate issue).

```
In [10]: pd.lib.infer_dtype([1,2,'a'])
Out[10]: 'mixed-integer'
```

@jreback It is to be compat with current `Series` behavior. In above case, `Series.str` is applied to all the elements and leave non-str as `NaN`.

```
s = pd.Series([1, 2, 'a'])
s.str.len()
# 0   NaN
# 1   NaN
# 2     1
# dtype: float64
```

comments.body: can you add a comment here on the impl, noting that we are explicity making element iterators
Added. If I understood you correctly what you are asking for.

Maybe the issue is here. Because DataFrame wants Python types, we have to convert from numpy to Python types. Before, this was done inside C (inside tolist call), now it is done in Python.

So in some way, this might require numpy to have an iterator reading out Python values, implemented in C, to make this same efficiency.

I would say that even leaving aside language differences, we are now making ``len(self._values)`` separate calls rather than a single one. We know numpy indexing has overhead, and I think this is perfectly acceptable.

**EDIT** I was missing the point, see my [last comment](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/20796#issuecomment-407388461).

Ha, I am looking at this now and I do not get anymore why we are mapping over a range here? We should map over values of `self._values` to cast them to Python using `self._values.item`. Was this my original code?
Yeah, [here's](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/commit/2773e3473cbf0a6cc875dc7c065172b7656f1f53) your commit.
Oh, I know. `item` wants an index of the item you want to get back.
